Award.AwardTitle: EMSW21-MCTP: eCIR: The expanded Center for Interdisciplinary Research
Award.AbstractNarration:
The expanded Center for Interdisciplinary Research (eCIR) will enable undergraduate students in statistics, applied mathematics, and computational mathematics - working in teams with faculty researchers across the disciplines - to experience the excitement of interdisciplinary research. This work extends the St. Olaf College Center for Interdisciplinary Research (CIR) supported under previous NSF grant. Students learn from the center how statistics serves as an interface with researchers in other disciplines, especially biology, psychology, and the social sciences. Applied and computational mathematics also provide a natural interface with other disciplines in the natural and social sciences. Two post-doctoral associates in applied or computational mathematics will be mentored under the auspices of eCIR. This project targets three transitions points: From early undergraduate student to undergraduate researcher; From undergraduate researcher to graduate student; From graduate school to teaching.

An explicit goal of the eCIR project is to substantially increase the number of students from traditionally underrepresented groups who participate in interdisciplinary undergraduate research and who then go on to graduate school in the mathematical sciences. In the natural sciences, undergraduate research is well-established; in the mathematical sciences, it is growing but still limited by a variety of factors such as faculty expertise and the identification of research problems accessible to undergraduates. The key components of this project are transferable to other institutions and plans for the project include intentional dissemination. We expect that what we learn from careful assessment and evaluation can make important contributions to the national conversation on the efficacy of undergraduate research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The long-range goal of the Enhancing the Mathematical Science Workforce for the 21st century (EMSW21) program is to increase the number of well-prepared U.S. citizens, nationals, and permanent residents who pursue careers in the mathematical sciences and in other NSF-supported disciplines.  With this grant, we have been able to develop programming that has been remarkably effective in attracting and retaining students in the mathematical sciences.  A centerpiece of this grant’s activities has been the Center for Interdisciplinary Research (CIR) where teams of students and faculty researchers come together to work on a diverse set of projects. The teams for the CIR consisted of a researcher from across campus (a domain expert), and a faculty member and three students from mathematical sciences.  Over the course of this grant, more than 100 students were involved in the CIR working on nearly 30 diverse projects with over 70 faculty. Teams explored such varied projects as aging, the cost and impact of hospital closings, alcoholism in adolsescent rats, human’s unique scent profiles, and exercise science. The students learned about their peer’s projects thereby broadening their exposure to the wide array of the types of problems that can be tackled by the mathematical sciences. Our experience has shown that working on real research problems with interdisciplinary teams generated interest and excited undergraduates about continuing study and potential careers in mathematical sciences.

Statistics — with its collaborative and interdisciplinary focus — was an appropriate and successful intellectual center of the original CIR. We saw applied mathematics and computational mathematics as the natural next step. Faculty in a variety of disciplines use sophisticated mathematics and computation to attack a host of interesting problems. Faculty researchers, especially in the natural sciences, welcomed the opportunity to collaborate with mentored, talented undergraduates with training in the appropriate areas of applied and computational mathematics. With this grant, data science was ushered in to this successful model thereby opening up a wider range of potential projects and research.  For example, applications in neuroscience, genetics and linguistics were then within reach.

With this funding, students honed their communication skills so that the results of their work were available in a number of different ways. They learned to communicate not only with mathematics mentors about technical issues, but also with others who did not have technical backgrounds. Students had the opportunity to present the results of their interdisciplinary research in a variety of ways, including oral presentations on campus and at conferences.  Over the years of the grant, students have presented their work in the form of posters at a large number of venues from National Council on Undergraduate Research conferences to domain-specific conferences and closer to home at the St. Olaf Honors Day Science Symposium.  All of the student teams wrote up the results of their research for the domain experts and some produced papers suitable for publication in professional journals. This funding also helped to support students involved in interdisciplinary research during the college’s 10-week summer research program.

 

Work funded with this grant has had a national impact on the curriculum of statistics and computational mathematics.  The field of statistics is progressing at a rapid pace and what once served as the core content for undergraduates needed updating.  The CIR supported by this grant was instrumental in identifying ways in which the core content could be extended and updated. As a result, a new text was produced by two of the PIs, Roback and Legler, which includes methods that are extremely useful in many areas of research done in the CIR but previously were not taught at the undergraduate level. Many programs across the country are adopting this text which came as a direct result of the CIR experience supported by this grant.

The CIR model was disseminated through publications in professional journals, numerous presentations at national conferences, visits by researchers to St. Olaf and visits by CIR participants to other institutions. Consequently, the CIR has served as a model for programs across the country ultimately multiplying the impact of this work. 

More than twenty-seven of the students participating in this program went on to advanced study in the mathematical sciences. Most of the other program alumni landed jobs related to the mathematical sciences.  It is safe to say that, wherever participants landed, their contributions to the workforce benefited by their participation in the CIR.
